positive.review:
First off, FOR ALL NEW PLAYERS: the new prologue and storyline starting from a later act are there for a reason. Since recent updates, the game's main story has become FULLY VOICED. All older acts can be played after completing a couple of missions, but they won't feature full voice acting. For this reason, the developers divided the main story into two sections. I'll also add that if you're having problems with "character graphical rendering," changing the game's "localization" should solve the problem. Google it or look in the discussions to see what that means. Now let's start talking specifically about everything else. 

Story:
So far, I'm enjoying everything. Story is presented to the player in the form of a visual novel. It's quite well done. We have a confrontation with a crazed AI, villains with their own agendas, and a tightly woven romance between adjutant and his charming squad. Yes, romance is part of the plot and involves several characters. These aren't fillers that ultimately have no connection to the story, so the game is officially a harem game. Thumbs up to the developers for the courage to make it official. Main character isn't just a cardboard cutout and has a personality. It's no surprise that female characters eventually fall for him.

Fanservice: 
This is worth mentioning right after the story. I've noticed that many people are writing about revealing outfits and so on, attributing the game to hentai and sexual content. First of all, as someone said earlier, hentai doesn't mean porn, but rather pervert. Secondly, there's no hentai here. This is high-quality fan service. The heroines' outfits, while revealing, are detailed and beautiful. Special credit to the developers for the skins. There's no sexual content as such. There are hints of intimate relationships, but all the characters are adults, so I don't see anything wrong with that. Perhaps someone's innocent soul considers a simple kiss sexual content. That's not the game's problem. 

Gameplay:
A fairly simple third-person shooter with varied character abilities. It's easy and enjoyable to play. Almost every character has their own combat style. There are numerous game modes, both more serious and mini-games. Game modes change with each update, with some returning more frequently, and others arriving later in a more polished form. The developers regularly conduct surveys about game modes and truly listen to ideas. So if you didn't like a mode, please leave a review. Who knows, maybe it will pleasantly surprise you next time. The only downside for me is that the normal game modes lack difficulty. But that's more my fault, as I'm used to setting every game to the hardest difficulty, otherwise I'll just get bored. It's worth adding that daily tasks can be completed in one minute. This is perfect for those who don't have time on certain days. There is also a base where you can interact with characters, buy them furniture and all sorts of other activities that are expanded with updates.

System:
I saw someone writing about freezing and such on excellent hardware. I haven't noticed any of that at all. My PC isn't top-of-the-line, but it's adequate. I play at 2K resolution on maximum settings with 120 fps without any freezing or drops. What can I say, I even managed to run the game normally on my old potato (previous PC). I think you should check your system and identify the problem if such drops are occurring. I have friends who play with similar hardware and also have no problems.

Gacha:
Since I started playing, I haven't spent a single penny on gacha. This is despite the fact that I have characters from every update. There's a 100% banner, and while there's a small chance of getting a character, just completing dailies, weeks, and events should easily be enough to get a character. This game also has double banners. Yeah, it sounds threatening, right? But with a double banner, the second character is given away for free. I haven't seen this tradition broken in over a year. Character copies are also optional. There's a tab where you can regularly obtain character parts. It might take time, but you can achieve the desired result. Of course, there's also the weapon banner, but I wouldn't say golden weapons are absolutely necessary. And then again, you can always save up extra spins. While not everyone has them, my characters do have personal guns. And a full upgrade only requires one more copy. Alternatively, there's a personal purple weapon. It can be fully upgraded simply by completing event objectives. That's all. The only thing that can really hit your wallet are the skins. I don't consider them expensive. However, given their quality and my desire to support the developers, I buy at least a couple with every update.

Epilogue:
After Destiny Child, which I played for a long time, closed, I wandered from game to game for a long time. However, my wanderings ended here. The game is truly well-made, the developers listen to the community and are constantly improving. My only hope is that someday they'll make suitable modes for those who enjoy higher difficulties like me. Ignore the dubious reviews and just try it for yourself. And I apologize for so many words.

I noticed this game has been review bombed by normie's, before that it had been sitting at 'very positive' since forever.
I'll quickly highlight some positives that has kept me with this game for over a year.



- Gameplay -

While not complex, nor having a high skill ceiling, the gameplay loop remains very fun. Characters kits are distinctive enough that it keeps the combat fresh. 

Important content can be completed without requiring meta teams and as a f2p, meaning you never feel locked out from progressing because you didn't swipe enough. The content for whales just gives an avatar frame that expires every week and some currency everyone gets in abundance.



- Events & Content Schedule -

Events rotate every 40+ days and typically consist of various game modes, there's something for everyone here, you have a few co-op modes, casual mini-games, wave defence, etc. 

Devs are very responsive to community feedback, so events that see re-runs are improved from previous versions. They've taken event modes I disliked in their first appearance and fine tuned them to make them very enjoyable.

Every event releases with a new character, and the ability to easily farm their optimal weapon that's often only slight worse than the banner weapon.



- Gacha -

At the end of the day, Snowbreak is a gacha, however although everyone will tell you their gacha is 'generous', Snowbreak actually is generous. Unlike other gacha's, you won't find yourself being forced to skip characters, you can get every character for for free and without heavy grinding.

Every character is usable at base copy, with dupes making them a bit stronger but not a night and day difference (barring 1 character), and weapon banners can 100% be ignored, but for those interested, you only need 1 extra copy to max the weapon, compared to the usual 5-6.




Ohh also, Fenny is best girl, anyone who says otherwise is lying.

Graphics are gorgeous and gameplay is good, but it has these bite-size little levels that take maybe 2 minutes to finish and that are completely linear and have no interactivity or possibility for exploration. As soon as I get in the groove, the level is over. The flow is terrible, and it just isn't satisfying. I'm assuming it is structured this way to force you to burn through your stamina faster. Given how little time you actually spend in each level, it seems unnecessary to have a team of 3 characters. Then, there are visual novel sections in between levels that take like 5 minutes to click through, which is, notably, longer than the actual levels. If these focused on lore and events I might be inclined to swiftly click through them, but I quickly started skipping them because they are full of cloying writing that focuses on the relationship between the self-insert protag and his waifu harem. A lot of the prose is also just flowery filler. I don't care about a breeze blowing through the autumn trees. Just let me shoot shit already.

Being an f2p gacha game, it has overly convoluted systems for everything from progression to currencies, and the UI is a nightmare to navigate. Anything and everything can be leveled up in minute detail, requiring materials that require grinding or money or whatever. You know the drill.

There is a lot of single-player content. There are at least 14 chapters in the main story, plus character-specific missions, time-limited chapters and events, and other activities you can do to get materials, etc. There don't seem to be any barriers if you just want to jump in and play the game normally, unless you approach this as a no-lifer, in which case you will hit a roadblock due to the stamina system.

A slick, stylish blend of third-person shooting and character-collection. It looks great, plays smoothly, and offers just enough depth to stay engaging.

Is it a great game?

Compared to other games outside of its genre i'd say its about average to decent at best

Compared to other games inside its own genre , its pretty high up there definitely within the top 10 (on my personal list its clearly and definitely sitting in my top 3 )

Is it a game anyone can play ? consdering its target audience i'd say no , i wouldnt recommend it to EVERYONE , just to people above the age of 20 , that being said , setting aside its aesthetic sensibilities and choice of romance trope the writers have chosen for the game's story , the story itself tackles psychological aspects and depicts situations that one must be both mentally and emotionally mature enough to understand 

Each and every character is well developed. 
Each and every character has their own troubles and tribulations to which some of us can relate to
Each and every character has a lot of depth and growth and none of them feel shallow or one dimensional

Gameplay? 
Its simple , robust and very straightforward 

Is it difficult ?
If you're the type that wants a challenge that makes his forehead sweat and his fingers tired from all the button mashing then you need to go play something else because this isnt the game for you 
This is a very casual and chill type of game where nothing's extremely difficult

Does it have PvP ? No and honestly ? its better this way , a thousand times better this way

Now its time to address the elephant in the room whenever this type of game genre comes up 

Does it have a Battle Pass , yes it does , does it turbo charge your progress by leaps and bounds ? Barely , it offers no advantage over the Free to play Player other than less time spent grinding for resources in one day

Now as far as the gacha game element goes , compared to others within its genre Snowbreak has a way more generous system and drop rates/chances , character banner re-runs happen very often and it has no "Limited time" characters that once their time's up they're gone for good , its not the kind of gacha game that's actively trying to dry out your wallet and turn it to ash 
So unless you're a habitual spender with poor impulse controll you can get pretty much all the characters at a decently sized pace

Once you pull your desired character you no longer need to  pull for more duplicates

Overall and In Summary 
Its not gonna be everyone's cup of tea , if you like it you like it , if you wanna keep playing it you'll keep playing it 
If you dont wanna keep playing it and you dont like it then you dont , you can go play something else since no one's holding you hostage other than yourself 

I love this game despite its quirkyness and lack of certain elements here and there but with enough time i'm sure they'll address them at

Overall i'll give it a 9.5/10

REVIEW:

I played the game back in closed beta, and sadly i kinda immediately knew it wasn't really going to survive. 

There just simply wasn't enough to do in the game to really justify playing it, coupled alongside a pretty boring and monotonous CO-OP mode you couldn't even really play with friends.

Fast forward to the game's 1 year anniversary and basically EVERYTHING had changed. 

It's interesting they went down the gooner route and even though that brings a lot of downsides, be it sometimes unrealistic depictions of how people act and the obligatory incels. 

They really turned the game around and it's a lot more fun. 

I do think adding more CO-OP game modes that aren't so restrictive is a good idea for the devs to take into account, but with the sheer amount of QOL improvement i've seen over that past year letting them do their thing certainly isn't hurting! 

This is one of the most generous and respectful gatcha games i've ever seen, regularly giving away entire free 5* characters and offering a very generous amount of paid currency for free every patch. 

Aside from some recent powercreep shenanigans they're generally pretty good at keeping everything balanced and since there isn't even really any reason to "tryhard" apart form bragging rights you never feel like you're explicitly missing out just because you don't have the TOP tier units. 

Tack on a story that honestly has so much more effort than you'd expect from a game that that primarily markets itself to the sad and lonely, I can wholehearted recommend this game even if you're not really into the gooner type games.

A truthful and honest BRAVO to the devs for saving the game!

[h1]Don't trust negative reviews![/h1]
As someone who started playing this game 8-9 months ago for the gameplay, trust me when I tell you to not trust the bad reviews. The game is getting hit with false tags and review bombs by tourists or a specific group that is jealous to see it doing incredibly well in other countries. Warframe players might remember us Tenno dealing with something similar from certain *ahem* "other games", so I'll state some facts and opinions on the game as someone who is more interested in the gameplay. Get ready for a lot of reading, and sorry if I repeat anything.

[h2]Facts:[/h2]
[olist]
 [*] Character banners come in 100% and 50/50%.

 [*] The gacha is honestly one of the best I've seen. If you are doing all of the events and content when they refresh you can typically earn enough to get the on banner character without ever spending money. I've been playing for 8-9 months now and have almost every character and I've only spent money on a banner twice, and that was purely because they had banner events to bring back old banner characters and I didn't wanna wait for them to come back around. The ONLY issue I have with this games gacha is the weapon banner. I think the weapon banners are an outdated monetization practice that paints characters into specific playstyles and takes away a players opportunity to play around with different builds and mechanics; But I feel this way for weapon banners in ANY game, not just Snowbreak.

 [*] The Devs seem to care more about fun than profits, so much so they are going to start giving away 5-star characters starting next patch (but we still get one this patch because its a summer event).

 [*] The gameplay loop feels repetitive at times but the dev's actually listen, I know this because they took one of my character kit concepts and divided it into 3 characters that exist in the game; And when players commented on the 5-star weapons, they adjusted it so that you'd only need 2 of them to max it out instead of 5 like other games.

 [*] They aren't afraid to try new things, even things people might find boring. A few events have come out that people weren't too keen on, but instead of repackaging it with an even shittier bow and shoving it down our throats like some other games do, they ask for feed back and actually use it to try and improve the events in fun ways that aren't contradictory of the games core themes.

 [*] There is no nudity or sexual content unless you believe a woman's body is not inherently sexual, and at that point the issue falls on you, not the game. Sure there are sexual innuendos and fan-service, but the only hentai are the people falsely labeling this game specifically to try and limit this games audience. And for the uninitiated, "hentai" means pervert, not porn.

 [*] The game isn't difficult to figure out and it doesn't force you to play a specific chapter and you can get right into the settings (unless something changed since I started); The people making those statements are doing so with malicious intent and I'd suggest trying it for yourself.

 [*] The new tutorial takes about 10 minutes if you skip all the dialogue; 20-25 if you don't. You can't edit settings at first but I'm sure that will be fixed. However, after doing your first character summon and being pushed into a mission, you'll be able to to pause and adjust settings while in the mission. So no, you're not forced to do 10-20 missions, people are just dumb lol.
[/olist]

[h2]Opinions:[/h2]
[olist]
 [*] The models are great. Anyone saying otherwise is using a potato phone or pc, and if I wanted opinions about potatoes I'd go to the nearest KFC and ask the Colonel or head to Five Guys and ask each of them to give me a fun fact... But I'm not gonna trust some dude with 0.3 hours of playtime to give me an honest review. Now do i think the graphics could use some improvement? Of course... But I also came to this game because it reminded me a bit of Warframe, so I'm spoiled and have seen them update their character models multiple times over 12+ years. The only true complaint I'd have is that the outfits, while really detailed, don't feel AS detailed as some other games. Do not come to this game expecting outfits on par with Love, Shinning, or Infinity Nikki... But I know if they did make the outfits look that good, they'd look absolutely stunning, especially the wedding dresses.

 [*] There is no nudity in the game, but as a fan of games with "battle damage" as a mechanic of gear, I personally wouldn't care if it did exist in that form. However I am aware that there are players that DO wish nudity existed in the game, but this isn't that kind of game. If you really want that, that is something you can probably find mods for, but this game is not a mature rated game so it's only cleavage and innuendos.

First off, FOR ALL NEW PLAYERS: the new prologue and storyline starting from a later act are there for a reason. Since recent updates, the game's main story has become FULLY VOICED. All older acts can be played after completing a couple of missions, but they won't feature full voice acting. For this reason, the developers divided the main story into two sections. I'll also add that if you're having problems with "character graphical rendering," changing the game's "localization" should solve the problem. Google it or look in the discussions to see what that means. Now let's start talking specifically about everything else. 

Story:
So far, I'm enjoying everything. Story is presented to the player in the form of a visual novel. It's quite well done. We have a confrontation with a crazed AI, villains with their own agendas, and a tightly woven romance between adjutant and his charming squad. Yes, romance is part of the plot and involves several characters. These aren't fillers that ultimately have no connection to the story, so the game is officially a harem game. Thumbs up to the developers for the courage to make it official. Main character isn't just a cardboard cutout and has a personality. It's no surprise that female characters eventually fall for him.

Fanservice: 
This is worth mentioning right after the story. I've noticed that many people are writing about revealing outfits and so on, attributing the game to hentai and sexual content. First of all, as someone said earlier, hentai doesn't mean porn, but rather pervert. Secondly, there's no hentai here. This is high-quality fan service. The heroines' outfits, while revealing, are detailed and beautiful. Special credit to the developers for the skins. There's no sexual content as such. There are hints of intimate relationships, but all the characters are adults, so I don't see anything wrong with that. Perhaps someone's innocent soul considers a simple kiss sexual content. That's not the game's problem. 

Gameplay:
A fairly simple third-person shooter with varied character abilities. It's easy and enjoyable to play. Almost every character has their own combat style. There are numerous game modes, both more serious and mini-games. Game modes change with each update, with some returning more frequently, and others arriving later in a more polished form. The developers regularly conduct surveys about game modes and truly listen to ideas. So if you didn't like a mode, please leave a review. Who knows, maybe it will pleasantly surprise you next time. The only downside for me is that the normal game modes lack difficulty. But that's more my fault, as I'm used to setting every game to the hardest difficulty, otherwise I'll just get bored. It's worth adding that daily tasks can be completed in one minute. This is perfect for those who don't have time on certain days. There is also a base where you can interact with characters, buy them furniture and all sorts of other activities that are expanded with updates.

System:
I saw someone writing about freezing and such on excellent hardware. I haven't noticed any of that at all. My PC isn't top-of-the-line, but it's adequate. I play at 2K resolution on maximum settings with 120 fps without any freezing or drops. What can I say, I even managed to run the game normally on my old potato (previous PC). I think you should check your system and identify the problem if such drops are occurring. I have friends who play with similar hardware and also have no problems.

Gacha:
Since I started playing, I haven't spent a single penny on gacha. This is despite the fact that I have characters from every update. There's a 100% banner, and while there's a small chance of getting a character, just completing dailies, weeks, and events should easily be enough to get a character. This game also has double banners. Yeah, it sounds threatening, right? But with a double banner, the second character is given away for free. I haven't seen this tradition broken in over a year. Character copies are also optional. There's a tab where you can regularly obtain character parts. It might take time, but you can achieve the desired result. Of course, there's also the weapon banner, but I wouldn't say golden weapons are absolutely necessary. And then again, you can always save up extra spins. While not everyone has them, my characters do have personal guns. And a full upgrade only requires one more copy. Alternatively, there's a personal purple weapon. It can be fully upgraded simply by completing event objectives. That's all. The only thing that can really hit your wallet are the skins. I don't consider them expensive. However, given their quality and my desire to support the developers, I buy at least a couple with every update.

Epilogue:
After Destiny Child, which I played for a long time, closed, I wandered from game to game for a long time. However, my wanderings ended here. The game is truly well-made, the developers listen to the community and are constantly improving. My only hope is that someday they'll make suitable modes for those who enjoy higher difficulties like me. Ignore the dubious reviews and just try it for yourself. And I apologize for so many words.

I usually don't post reviews on games, but with the recent Discord advertisement and the review bombings I decided to post a review of what I think of the game. 

PROS:
This game is full on a fanservice waifu collector where countless women fall under your spell because "you're so perfect and awesome and cool and stuff". It's very much a power fantasy and has been for quite some time. It's not shy about giving the player the full harem experience, to the point whee you are CANONICALLY married to multiple women. Not only is the story full of master love, but the characters are diverse and all have their different quirks that makes them stand out from each other. It's also a nice touch that each new patch brings more detailed models and environments, making it quite hypnotyzing to look at. Personally, I'm glad the devs are sticking to their guns and telling a fantastical story where the main character (self-insert) can just have fun and enjoy being the hero of the game.

Really, all of that doesn't matter because this is a gacha game and we all know how they make their money. Power-creep, weapon banners, FOMO, you know the drill. However, I'm very much surprised to see how painless the gacha system is. A 100% banner for chars and weapons? Really a huge breath of fresh air to know your months of grind actually pay off instead of being stolen by a 50-50. That's not all. The game actively showers you with currency, pulls, and even free characters all the time. Why, you ask? Because their skins, and interactive skins, are the real bread winners. The skins + interactive skins are probably the most value you can find in a gacha game. You're telling me for ~$30 I get a character skin, weapon skin, and multiple interactive scenes for a character?  A lot of popular harem gacha games charge more just for a skin! Now the weird/conflated pricing for the premium currency does make it hard to tell how much you're actually spending, but if you do become a spender, I recommend the monthly pass or the $50 premium currency purchase (first timers get double the value) for the most bang-for-your-buck. 

CONS:
Now, I want to say that I LOVE this game and that this game is perfect and blah blah blah but it's not. I started out from when the story was starting to embrace the fan service and moving away from the "tacticool" style. I really like that they are fully embracing a new identity that the fans enjoy, but the game play suffers as a result. A lot of the shooting aspects of the game have been sidelined for abilities that instagib the enemies with little need to even fire your weapon. It's almost too easy! Then again, it's been a while since I played it as a mobile game (I switched to PC a long time ago and the PC controls feel much better to play.) 

Additionally, the story is being re-written to accompany this new change in direction, so the new retcons and "prologue" is an awkward middle child that players kinds have to ignore while the story re-writes occur. You'll notice the girls become more profound in their love to the point where you wonder how the adjuntant (MC) has the time to escape the bedroom! I really hope the writers put more work into the realities of juggling the many current (and new) partners but we all know that's probably not going to happen.

CONCLUSION:
It's a power fantasy where you're Mr. #1 and all the girls swoon over you and think you're the next best thing since sliced bread. If that's not your thing then that's fine, but for those who like that then this is the game for you. The game is packed full of content that will keep you entertained while the patch progresses and you get your free anime girls to boot. 

If this doesn't sell you, then I don't know what will.

NOTE: If you actually want to experience the game without censorship, go into the localization file and change the "0" to a "1". If you don't know what that means or where to go, there are guides specifically on how to find and change this file. (Just wanted to spread awareness for the uninformed.)

I noticed this game has been review bombed by normie's, before that it had been sitting at 'very positive' since forever.
I'll quickly highlight some positives that has kept me with this game for over a year.



- Gameplay -

While not complex, nor having a high skill ceiling, the gameplay loop remains very fun. Characters kits are distinctive enough that it keeps the combat fresh. 

Important content can be completed without requiring meta teams and as a f2p, meaning you never feel locked out from progressing because you didn't swipe enough. The content for whales just gives an avatar frame that expires every week and some currency everyone gets in abundance.



- Events & Content Schedule -

Events rotate every 40+ days and typically consist of various game modes, there's something for everyone here, you have a few co-op modes, casual mini-games, wave defence, etc. 

Devs are very responsive to community feedback, so events that see re-runs are improved from previous versions. They've taken event modes I disliked in their first appearance and fine tuned them to make them very enjoyable.

Every event releases with a new character, and the ability to easily farm their optimal weapon that's often only slight worse than the banner weapon.



- Gacha -

At the end of the day, Snowbreak is a gacha, however although everyone will tell you their gacha is 'generous', Snowbreak actually is generous. Unlike other gacha's, you won't find yourself being forced to skip characters, you can get every character for for free and without heavy grinding.

Every character is usable at base copy, with dupes making them a bit stronger but not a night and day difference (barring 1 character), and weapon banners can 100% be ignored, but for those interested, you only need 1 extra copy to max the weapon, compared to the usual 5-6.

I have been playing this game for over a year now through their official launcher. Downloaded it for review purposes. 

This is an incredible game with fun gameplay and amazing characters you can officially marry in-game. This game is in a niche of it's own with how in-depth you can have a relationship with your waifus in a gacha. 
The story is also pretty fun, and you get to play as a based adjutant who makes brilliant strategic decisions and takes good care of all his girls at the same time.
As this is a gacha, you might think it's very monetization heavy, but that's not the case at all. There is a 100% guarantee banner and you can easily pull a character every patch. You can get their 4 star weapon for free from events, and the grind is pretty easy. But that's not all, because every other patch they give you a free character (who is actually pretty strong unlike most gacha games) and starting November, they will be giving out a free character every patch! 
The events are unique and creative, like they even had fun mini-games like cart racing and a jetpack joyride styled mode. And there's also a base where you can further interact with all your waifus.

The monetization is mostly for the skins and interactive scenes. But as someone who owns most of the interactable scenes in the game, they are WELL worth the money. I don't regret buying them for a single second. I also love how seriously Seasun takes player feedback. I am glad to be able to play a gacha game that actually values their playerbase.

If you like fanservice, master-love or fun gunplay, then definitely give it a go!

Graphics are gorgeous and gameplay is good, but it has these bite-size little levels that take maybe 2 minutes to finish and that are completely linear and have no interactivity or possibility for exploration. As soon as I get in the groove, the level is over. The flow is terrible, and it just isn't satisfying. I'm assuming it is structured this way to force you to burn through your stamina faster. Given how little time you actually spend in each level, it seems unnecessary to have a team of 3 characters. Then, there are visual novel sections in between levels that take like 5 minutes to click through, which is, notably, longer than the actual levels. If these focused on lore and events I might be inclined to swiftly click through them, but I quickly started skipping them because they are full of cloying writing that focuses on the relationship between the self-insert protag and his waifu harem. A lot of the prose is also just flowery filler. I don't care about a breeze blowing through the autumn trees. Just let me shoot shit already.

Being an f2p gacha game, it has overly convoluted systems for everything from progression to currencies, and the UI is a nightmare to navigate. Anything and everything can be leveled up in minute detail, requiring materials that require grinding or money or whatever. You know the drill.

There is a lot of single-player content. There are at least 14 chapters in the main story, plus character-specific missions, time-limited chapters and events, and other activities you can do to get materials, etc. There don't seem to be any barriers if you just want to jump in and play the game normally, unless you approach this as a no-lifer, in which case you will hit a roadblock due to the stamina system.

[h3] Improvement Ideas [/h3]
Seasun, please spend more time designing the actual game instead of focusing more on events. I will give extreme credit to the dev team for the Cerulean Getaway update. The minigames in this patch are phenomenal, and I am really proud of their work in being able to add them to Snowbreak. However, I am [b]BEGGING[/b] you, most players end up leaving due to shallow gameplay, except for the degenerates like me who can't stop playing gachas. There are even ideas to improve the game that don't change the gameplay loop, like changing anything that isn't combat to be faster. Puzzles and interactions are painfully slow, like you might as well embed YouTube to keep me from just staring at my monitor thinking about why I'm doing this to myself.

It could be fun to make level selection more engaging, use features like the Base to give a player another reason to use the base if they want, but still keep the current click menu option. Think of Brown Dust II in their menu design.

For combat, please rebalance the design, make supports more than just damage buffers to make your current limited operative OP you can easily add healing/shielding or movement into their kit while raising the enemy damage. Also, greatly increase the critical hit scaling; this just makes shooters more satisfying. Rebalancing the importance of healing/shields lets players sustain enough to burst down enemies with head shots or buffs, or play with positioning and [b]FINALLY[/b] put use to your forgotten cover mechanic. This one creates more engagement with team building and combat while still giving players options to do whatever they want. You could even make a new operator gaining buffs using the cover mechanic. However, this will drastically change the current gameplay, so these combat ideas could be superficial.

Combat flow is terrible. Walking miles across an empty map in a linear, pointed direction, and when you hit the late game, you instantly evaporate everything, and then keeping walking is not engaging. In some way, make the player move faster, either naturally or through supports or even add vehicles. Change the damage scaling depending on body parts, increase the damage for crits and head shots. Also, make snipers different, just being a long-range spam shoot that tickles is boring. They have no power when hitting head shots unless you are playing a mission that you are over-leveled in.

For operative balance, if they do rebalance combat and don't want to change operatives, then make supports be more meaningful. With a bigger support impact, at least players can still opt to use older operatives with stronger support. Again, credit to the dev team in the Cerulean Getaway update, with the new Fenny being refreshing to play.

Level design, think of Call of Duty campaigns, you mainly do the kill all enemies, but some change objectives. Could add a sniper level that isn't operative locked, or give them the option to let the players learn and use what they want. Another could be clearing an area and then surviving for some time, or just surviving in an area with turrets you can place on the map that you have to repair if damaged. These can be in the main story or just side levels you use from time to time. Something new to break the pattern of slop that is the same thing, but put a few mechanics in that are either new or old, and call it done. Also, change level transitions. If you really want to keep the core feature of shooting, then why tf are we spending more time in menus than playing? Instead of leaving the scene to go menu to menu, keep the player in the level, then prompt if they want to continue and generate the next level inside with seamless loading, like turning the camera to look behind while the operative walks/runs to load the next area. It's okay if the animation locks during big packets. At least it beats clicking static buttons and menus just to load for 2 total minutes. Edit: In the Defiant Bloom update, they do attempt the sniper mission in the event story, which was great. It was a bit stiff in nature, but I love that they are trying. Good stuff from the dev team. I hope this new design approach moves into the actual main story. If they find it hard to rebalance the current design, then adding these new mission ideas will help a lot.

Skins could be more than what they currently are, and would make more money. For starters, add more effects like unique bullets/shooting or reloading effects/animations that are easily noticeable if you don't want to put more work into them. The biggest thing to add to skins is making them interactive in combat, each kill scales to the effect, or head shots make the skin do something, literally anything. Also, the game censors itself by default, but it is really easy to disable it even though it isn't in the game settings. For those that complain then maybe add a settings option that tones down the fan service and slightly alters designs, say a skirt is too short, then make one that is longer. Either way, I still buy their skins because I like the game and I think they look great. It just isn't godly, and in most cases, I say not worth it. They have been getting better after the Defiant Bloom update. This also adds value that skins are customizable, also regarding modding, it's odd behavior to spend resources countering mods when we can barely use them to improve our game. . .

Gacha system needs to fix the rate of income, for the rate of banners rotating compared to how much rewards give is horrendous. You can get around 20-40 pulls each event, and pity is 80 for 50/50 on operatives or 60 on weapons, with a direct power creep next event. If you take other gacha games seriously, then this one is not for you. The main reason for pulling in this game is if you like the character, and that is [b]ALL[/b]. There is no important mode that rotates for currency. They only rotate modes for materials, which only matters to the small percentage of players that want to max stats for a handful of modes that care about that.

The stamina system needs to be tweaked. The stamina system is so bad that they give you tons of items that restore stamina so you can continue playing. Why not rebalance the stamina or integrate those items into the stamina naturally, rather than using items that expire at that point? One positive is the other stamina system to farm shards to build copies of your owned operatives, even if it is painfully slow and capped to prevent quick upgrades. 

[h3] TLDR [/h3] 
The game is unique, but it loses its charm after a few plays, and then you uninstall it, or you hate gooners and don't install. Sound design is 50/50, some good, some negligible. Art, graphics, and controls are good, but the gameplay loop contradicts its core design, making the game feel like it pushes you away, regardless of whether you like easy mobile game designs or shooters. The best feature is event minigames, which are popular games converted to fit within Snowbreak. Shooting = coolish, game balance = not cool, daily grind = extremely easy, max grind = jobless, skins = paid mostly, gacha = income painly slow but good odds, gooner = with more updates.

Snowbreak is by no means a bad game. sure it has jank. so if you are looking for a gacha game that is as polished as genshin, honkai, zzz or wuwa, you won't get it here.
The missions hae major stutters, even when i fps-lock to 60fps. and that is with a 3080, 32gb of ram and an i9 running the game at high graphics setting and under.
Is the combat good then? is 'aight at best, every encounter feels like i use a nuke on a rat. the cover mechanic is useless, since i can tank all damage, and never get under 30% HP. 
But for me, the worst is the sound, specifically the sound effects of explosions and guns. they all feel lackluster and without oomf.
But that being said, i really do enjoy the gameplay loop, the graphics and the story i did understand.

However, if you are a gooner gamer like me, this is THE perfect game for you. As the MC of the game, it seems like you are in a pseudo-relationship with all of the operators (the gacha girls if you will).

I say pseudo-relationship for one reason only. i did not ever get the chance to find out.
I was lucky enough to experience a story glitch so aneurysm-indusing, that i HAVE to give this gacha game a negative review.

What happened you might ask? Glad you didn't ask. I had just gotten around halfway into the second chapter, and decided to call it a night.
when i log in next, i am FORCED into chapter 14 part 2, with no way to go back to where i should be in the story.
So i contact support, and what do they say? They tell me to follow the guide to switch chapter. "yes!" i thought to myself, only to go in and find out i needed to complete chapter 15 part 2 and another story to do so.

So now i am up to date with the story, have no idea what, why, when or why i should care.
So if you are unlucky enough to get the same glitch as me, i can only reccommend a quick unintall.

[h3] Improvement Ideas [/h3]
Seasun, please spend more time designing the actual game instead of focusing more on events. I will give extreme credit to the dev team for the Cerulean Getaway update. The minigames in this patch are phenomenal, and I am really proud of their work in being able to add them to Snowbreak. However, I am [b]BEGGING[/b] you, most players end up leaving due to shallow gameplay, except for the degenerates like me who can't stop playing gachas. There are even ideas to improve the game that don't change the gameplay loop, like changing anything that isn't combat to be faster. Puzzles and interactions are painfully slow, like you might as well embed YouTube to keep me from just staring at my monitor thinking about why I'm doing this to myself.

It could be fun to make level selection more engaging, use features like the Base to give a player another reason to use the base if they want, but still keep the current click menu option. Think of Brown Dust II in their menu design.

For combat, please rebalance the design, make supports more than just damage buffers to make your current limited operative OP you can easily add healing/shielding or movement into their kit while raising the enemy damage. Also, greatly increase the critical hit scaling; this just makes shooters more satisfying. Rebalancing the importance of healing/shields lets players sustain enough to burst down enemies with head shots or buffs, or play with positioning and [b]FINALLY[/b] put use to your forgotten cover mechanic. This one creates more engagement with team building and combat while still giving players options to do whatever they want. You could even make a new operator gaining buffs using the cover mechanic. However, this will drastically change the current gameplay, so these combat ideas could be superficial.

Combat flow is terrible. Walking miles across an empty map in a linear, pointed direction, and when you hit the late game, you instantly evaporate everything, and then keeping walking is not engaging. In some way, make the player move faster, either naturally or through supports or even add vehicles. Change the damage scaling depending on body parts, increase the damage for crits and head shots. Also, make snipers different, just being a long-range spam shoot that tickles is boring. They have no power when hitting head shots unless you are playing a mission that you are over-leveled in.

For operative balance, if they do rebalance combat and don't want to change operatives, then make supports be more meaningful. With a bigger support impact, at least players can still opt to use older operatives with stronger support. Again, credit to the dev team in the Cerulean Getaway update, with the new Fenny being refreshing to play.

Level design, think of Call of Duty campaigns, you mainly do the kill all enemies, but some change objectives. Could add a sniper level that isn't operative locked, or give them the option to let the players learn and use what they want. Another could be clearing an area and then surviving for some time, or just surviving in an area with turrets you can place on the map that you have to repair if damaged. These can be in the main story or just side levels you use from time to time. Something new to break the pattern of slop that is the same thing, but put a few mechanics in that are either new or old, and call it done. Also, change level transitions. If you really want to keep the core feature of shooting, then why tf are we spending more time in menus than playing? Instead of leaving the scene to go menu to menu, keep the player in the level, then prompt if they want to continue and generate the next level inside with seamless loading, like turning the camera to look behind while the operative walks/runs to load the next area. It's okay if the animation locks during big packets. At least it beats clicking static buttons and menus just to load for 2 total minutes. Edit: In the Defiant Bloom update, they do attempt the sniper mission in the event story, which was great. It was a bit stiff in nature, but I love that they are trying. Good stuff from the dev team. I hope this new design approach moves into the actual main story. If they find it hard to rebalance the current design, then adding these new mission ideas will help a lot.

Skins could be more than what they currently are, and would make more money. For starters, add more effects like unique bullets/shooting or reloading effects/animations that are easily noticeable if you don't want to put more work into them. The biggest thing to add to skins is making them interactive in combat, each kill scales to the effect, or head shots make the skin do something, literally anything. Also, the game censors itself by default, but it is really easy to disable it even though it isn't in the game settings. For those that complain then maybe add a settings option that tones down the fan service and slightly alters designs, say a skirt is too short, then make one that is longer. Either way, I still buy their skins because I like the game and I think they look great. It just isn't godly, and in most cases, I say not worth it. They have been getting better after the Defiant Bloom update. This also adds value that skins are customizable, also regarding modding, it's odd behavior to spend resources countering mods when we can barely use them to improve our game. . .

Gacha system needs to fix the rate of income, for the rate of banners rotating compared to how much rewards give is horrendous. You can get around 20-40 pulls each event, and pity is 80 for 50/50 on operatives or 60 on weapons, with a direct power creep next event. If you take other gacha games seriously, then this one is not for you. The main reason for pulling in this game is if you like the character, and that is [b]ALL[/b]. There is no important mode that rotates for currency. They only rotate modes for materials, which only matters to the small percentage of players that want to max stats for a handful of modes that care about that.

The stamina system needs to be tweaked. The stamina system is so bad that they give you tons of items that restore stamina so you can continue playing. Why not rebalance the stamina or integrate those items into the stamina naturally, rather than using items that expire at that point? One positive is the other stamina system to farm shards to build copies of your owned operatives, even if it is painfully slow and capped to prevent quick upgrades. 

[h3] TLDR [/h3] 
The game is unique, but it loses its charm after a few plays, and then you uninstall it, or you hate gooners and don't install. Sound design is 50/50, some good, some negligible. Art, graphics, and controls are good, but the gameplay loop contradicts its core design, making the game feel like it pushes you away, regardless of whether you like easy mobile game designs or shooters. The best feature is event minigames, which are popular games converted to fit within Snowbreak. Shooting = coolish, game balance = not cool, daily grind = extremely easy, max grind = jobless, skins = paid mostly, gacha = income painly slow but good odds, gooner = with more updates.

Way too much clicking on text for the story to continue so I just skip it altogether. The game settings during the ~30 min long tutorial are a joke as you can change exactly three aspects of keyboard sensitivity and that's it. No graphic settings or audio settings whatsoever.

The combat felt fun at first as you fight your way through a bunch of enemies at once with different kinds of enemies appearing after time. But once I stopped shooting and let the enemies attack me I found out that they are pretty much useless and I could stand still for 5 mins or more without getting killed.

Well how can i start this ?, this is pretty much the first i time i ever touched a gacha adjacent game and i know this kind of genre have some "quirks" that may not be appealing to the general masses so i wont judge the game on these "intergral" features, with that out of the way i will talk about the aspect not influence by the genre
-Gameplay: I genuinely dont know if this is the quirk of the genre but my god the gunplay is so boring like watching literal paint dry, no recoil, no feeling, aiming is pretty much for show, enemies is brain-dead, singular attack strategy, lacking variations leading to stale engagements and bosses are so easy it is trivial, dodging is not exactly needed because why would you dodge when you can just walk out of the attacks like youre on a stroll in the park, overall lacking energy and not engaging
-Characters: i know the game is supposed to be an eye candy type of game but like can they at least try some uniqe spin, twist on the tropes of each of these characters, they are like straight up walking tropes of every single character types from the interaction down to the design but with perfect physique for maxium "attractiveness", overall generic, uninspiring, forgettable, the voice actors performance sometimes feel forced and too scripted, sometime feel unbothered like they just want to get over this fast, and the whole experience feel like those cheap and cliche-filled isekai anime with the diolauges
-Sound: average, run of the mill sound effects and music, corporate and feel manufactured, overall unimpressive and so dont expect much
-Lore&Interactions: for some reason the game made me walk through 45 minutes of boredom-inducing gameplay and dialouges before the exposition and general world building, when playing i keep questioning what the heck are these things you guys talk about and general very confused, onto the interations, without build up of the relationships and character developments every single activities and voicelines by each characters feel so distant, foreign you dont really have a connection or resonate with their interactions at all, as a matter of fact i just skip the voicelines and just straight up read and skip all of their dialouge to obtain the information on lore and thats it, dont really feel the need or the drive to really sit and watch them interacting 
I came in expecting nothing and came out expecting even less, if you want to play some barely passable gunplay,boring gameplay and like watching anime girls then i think this could be your thing but if you want something of higher caliber then look somwhere else
This game went from pretty fun with some gooner bait to just pure gooner bait with no fun

TLDR: Mobile crap ported to PC...skip it. 
The intro is classic Asian-gatcha design....an overly convoluted post-apocalypse jargon-laced blab followed by micro-seconds of gameplay between each hard stop forcing you to perform an obvious, specific action. Can't even interact with the main menu (once you get there) because the game is tutorializing how to start the next mission by pressing the *confused gasp* "Play Next Mission" button...how would I EVER have figured THAT out!?! The first character is the stereotypical asian-robo-girl that has no emotions...how endearing: a null blank of a person *sigh*.
Each mission is about 2 minutes of walking down a street, blasting a few enemies and it's over, show an array of probably worthless loot and progress-bar levelling-up animation. If I wasn't on an SSD, it would probably take longer to load to and from each mission than it took to actualy play the mission.

Too much Goon not enough Game, tried it solely for the Discord orbs. The game play is good overall, but its way too easy. On top of that I don't want or need the characters to be calling me, "darling" every 15 seconds so I probably won't play much more of this game. I also noticed the camera gets locked and you don't have much freedom to look around in some levels.
It's got an interesting game's framework, just has a few small issues, and the relationship with the characters is just not for me.  I can see why the game has a player base though.
